results.content:
I have done several React Courses, and this one is by far the best one not only in Udemy but also in the entire Internet. Yes I said it the Internet. 

Andrew teaching style and approach is incredible easy to follow and learn. Even though I already know so many things that Andrew is teaching, I do every single section/homework/exercise because in almost every lesson I learned something new or a better way to do it.

Thanks for making such a great course and focusing on teaching so many details to understand better the parts that make up for the React/Redux Ecosystem. For example regarding the Redux section,  this is the first time that I learn Redux separated from React, and I was able to grasp so many details by building it from scratch that I ingored before this course.

Will follow up your courses closely to make sure that I continue learning so much in my path to Full Stack Developer Mastery.

Best Regards,
Rafael

results.content: I absolutely love Andrew Mead and have used many of his courses.  However, not using create-react-app killed this class for me. I understand he wants to show what babel, webpack, and such do, but it would have been much simpler to use create-react-app and then have sections dedicated to just babel or the other parts.   This one was a miss for me, but I still recommend all of his other classes.

results.content:
This course started out awesome and part 1 was done beautifully but part 2 was long, boring, and torture to get through. The redux part imparticular was so confusing I had to go to YouTube to get it before returning to complete those sections. Towards the end of completing the Expensify App, you're so lost that you're just copying the code because you've already invested 20 hours and want to at least have something to add to your portfolio. I hate just copying the instructor's code because NONE of the information is retained. 

Andrew speaking cadence wears on you after a while and it's just code after code after code with little visual aids.

I'm currently finishing up where we're connecting react and redux and I want this course to be over.

I did enjoy learning to create a react app from scratch without create-react-app because now I know what all the pieces in CRA are doing behind the scenes. 

It's a good course but it's a serious chore to get through, could have been done in less time, and you'll spend time with other better-explained resources often before returning to the course to complete that section. By the end of it, you'll have learned a lot but you'll also be glad it's over.

Up until this course I was mainly focused in server-side development (Java, C++). This course gave me a comprehensive introduction, not only to React but also to the entire Front-End Eco-system.
The way I approached the course is to have the video play while I write the code along with the video, this may seem tedious but that way you remember the concepts as well as the code better.
Dear Andrew, I have enjoyed all of the content you've created and I am very grateful for the time you took to make this course what it is.

Thank you Andrew!

results.content:
EDIT: editing my review one year later. I went back a few months ago and picked up Section 19 to learn about hooks, and then I went job hunting. I am now employed as a front end developer for a small-ish web development company and I am absolutely loving it. I use what I learned in this course every single day, working primarily on responsive React websites, and I was able to do it without spending thousands of dollars on one of those professional bootcamps (full disclosure: I do have prior experience in programming and a couple of STEM degrees). Thanks again Andrew!

This course was incredible. I started out knowing absolutely nothing about React or Redux or any of the other topics covered, and I was only about halfway through Andrew's JS Bootcamp when I began. Even so, the lessons were very easy to follow (I do have prior programming experience which probably made things easier for me) and I really appreciated the exercises to keep my brain from zoning out, and especially the section on deployment to Heroku so I could produce actual production apps. I've already started building some basic demo apps for my portfolio, and I couldn't have done it without this course. Also: the Q&A section is regularly monitored by Andrew and his assistant(s); all of my questions were answered by one of them in less than 24 hours, and very frequently less than 12 hours. That is the reason why this is a 5-star course. (FYI this review is only for sections 1-13, I haven't yet gone through the other sections)

results.content:
This is the course to take if you want to get a fundamental understanding of React, Redux, react-redux and react-router. Andrew's ground-up approach helps you grasp the fundamentals and then build on your knowledge throughout the course and he gives you an increasing amount opportunities to use what you learned as the course progresses.

I would like to have seen more coverage and use of React lifecycle methods. It would have been helpful to see more working examples to better understand when and how to use them.

This is one of the best courses I've taken on Udemy so far. Andrew did a fantastic job crafting this course. I'm looking forward to more advanced courses!

results.content:
I am currently learning React from this course  and a Coding Boot Camp. This is a great course for me because it really reinforces everything I am learning with the Boot Camp.

After completing the course, I have found it to be extremely helpful. I recently completed the Coding Boot Camp and I found that Andrew's React course was much more in depth and thorough in explanation. Some of the material is a little out dated, but that is to be expected in this industry. Andrew did a great job of jumping in and updating his course, and in places where there wasn't an update it made me learn how debug and find other resources on the web. The TA Adam did an excellent job of responding to my questions as well.

I would definitely recommend this course to beginner and to anyone who is looking to sharpen their skills with React!

results.content:
After chipping away at this course over a month, I have finally completed it, and now I feel like i have a sense of empowerment.
I'm excited to take what I've learnt to try and make my own web apps.
Andrew has done an excellent job crafting this course. I really enjoyed how we built the app up from the ground, without a boilerplate, slowly added new elements, building up to a powerful and complete final product. This course is more then just react, you will learn many other elements which all piece together to perform a professional production app. 
I'm looking forward to future courses by Andrew, and I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is looking to start and understand React.

results.content:
This is THE COURSE you should take if you want to learn React!

The professor explains things in a very clear manner, and in the end of most lectures he gives you a homework - not a homework that is silly and easy to do, but a homework that will actually challenge you. This is the best way to solidify and make things stick to your mind.

He is also always helping you if you get stuck. If you have any question, you can ask and Andrew himself or another student will be there to help you solve any problem you can be facing with your code.

results.content:
I just completed this incredibly comprehensive, engaging course and am truly in awe of what Andrew has put together. Not only did he make React easily digestible but he also introduced a variety of tools that are relevant to the real world application of the framework and software development in general. He considered every angle in planning this course, with lessons that often answered my questions as soon as I thought of them. I learned so much more than I anticipated but at a pace that was rarely, if ever, overwhelming. And I am walking away feeling confident in my knowledge and newly-acquired skills, but with projects, boilerplates, and lessons I can and will reference time and again.

Admittedly, as a former decade-long teacher, I can be a tough critic at times when wearing my student hat, but I have to say, I was endlessly impressed with Andrew's style and abilities. I hope some day I can be equally as articulate when talking about development tools, like React. Thank you, Andrew, for simplifying this process and making it fun. Please keep teaching and creating.

results.content:
Andrew is a great instructor...he doesn't rush along and really hits on the basics in a way that is thorough and descriptive. The dude is truly a great communicator. Also, the challenges (code-it-yourself exercises included in most videos) are awesome and force me to think, so I don't fall pray to that passive online video daze. Awesome course so far to learn React.

There's a lot of content here, but it's set up in a way that is iterative. I only have a month or so before school starts up again, but I've felt comfortable, even if I only do 3 videos a day. Each video touches on an important concept.

Also, you WILL improve your ES6/ES7 knowledge greatly when taking this course, something I really appreciate.

results.content:
This course was recommended to me by someone I met at a coding Meetup, but I'm about a quarter of the way in and I'm not sure if by the end of it I will feel like I've developed a firm understanding of React/Redux.

So far, I REALLY like his "challenges" opportunities but I feel like I'm suffering from his lack of clear explanation. He doesn't go as indepth as he could in explaining topics and reiterating them to get it to stick---often he'll mention "Go to MDN for more information," which makes me think why did I purchase a course for the instructor to just say MDN MDN MDN? I know MDN is a valuable tool but I often find Andrew explaining something briefly, then I would have to pause the video and go google something for further reading... which isn't bad, but the point of my buying this course is to have someone explain and demonstrate it to me and not just me scourging articles as I have done previously.

I'm also a bit peeved with the "Indecision App" which to be honest is just a modified todo app. I guess I was expecting more "real app" experiences like with Colt Steele's YelpCamp project and not just another todo app. Hopefully it'll get better :/

results.content:
I am about half way through and i am really enjoying the course. The teacher goes slow, explains everything very well, and then usually has you apply what he taught you to a different app. This forces you to make sure you REALLY understood what he just said.

The only complaint i have, is you need to name each thing differently. for example he uses  props and functions with the same name. Well when i come back after a day or two, i can't tell what is being used, the prop or the function. So i started naming them differently (one example: handleDeleteOptionMethod > handleDeleteOptionPropOne > handleDeleteOptionPropTwo) That way, when i come back to my work, i know what is being used and where it came from.

results.content:
I would have given six stars if I could - quality of lessons, comprehensive nature of course and excellence of instructor (Andrew).
My only gripe is that the course was originally written in 2017 and there have been several major releases and updates to packages since then, consequently it was sometimes frustrating ensuring that the latest configurations worked. That said, the Q&A was a fantastic resource and other students were quick to share their experiences and work arounds.
Also, the final section (added more recently) is a "must see" as it tackles the latest features of React which will make development far more streamlined.

results.content: I'm only in Section 4.30, but I wanted to take a minute to make a comment about Andrew as an instructor. Sometimes you don't realize how good someone is until you take a course from a different instructor on the same topic. I enrolled in another class (which shall remain nameless) with an instructor that obviously has the React knowledge required, but what that instructor does not have is the same innate teaching skills that Andrew has. Teaching requires more than just a grasp of the subject matter: in order to truly teach you must be able to create an environment where the student is both engaged and challenged. Programming is truly a hands-on skill and you cannot spend the first several hours of a course innundating students with a plethora of slides and theory or you're going to lose them. Andrew does an excellent job of explaining concepts as you go thru the course, but he then proceeds to show you how to apply those concepts to the subject matter. He shows you everything you need to know to accomplish something – usually in a previous video – and then challenges you to accomplish the task on your own. Then, he immediatelty shows you how to do it after you start the video. I learned quite a bit in the other class that I took of his and I'm learning quite a bit in this one. That other class I mentioned? Not so much...

results.content:
Andrew and Adam are the Batman and Robin of this online teaching.  Andrew is extremely thorough.  I've taken several courses on Udemy.  Each instructor has strengths and weaknesses to me.  What I appreciate about this course is that Andrew, not only explains, but also shows how react connects to java, and I believe he lays a proper foundation.  Adam is also very good with addressing issues.  Perhaps, more importantly, I believe their patience may be unmatched when it comes to resolving issues.

Andrew also has source code with each lecture.  Not all instructors provide that.  This makes it convenient, when you make a small error, that can be remedied by finding the issue in the source.

Another benefit that I am coming to appreciate is that Andrew challenges early and often.  

 A suggestion I might add is Andrew should create  a full stack or have a course on how to connect node with react.

Thanks,

Keep up the Great Work!

results.content:
I've been programming for the better part of 3.5 months now. I love it, but it's definitely been a rollercoaster. I have times where I can pick things up with almost little to no practice, while other things still elude me a month later. One of those is React, but Andrew's course has helped me a ton with the building anxiety. Plus, he has taught me things I didn't know otherwise and I have found useful. I have not completed the course yet and if I do, I will do my best to update this review to reflect my new opinion at that point.

However, if you are confident with your JS, or ES6 and want to move on to learning React, this course is perfect for that. It will even brush up on the necessary ES6 for building in React. I hope you benefit from this course as much as I have. 

Thanks Andrew, Philly coders unite!

results.content:
It is enjoyable and I learnt a lot about React. As a beginner it took a little longer for some of the concepts to sink in, but the challenges and guidance helped a lot. 

The Q&A for this course is a goldmine, fast, accurate, detailed and importantly helpful responses from both Andrew and his team and other students

I cant wait to put my new skills to use.

The updates to accommodate new ES6/7 features upsets the flow the videos a little, which can be a bit jarring, but its good to see that the course is update to reflect new JS or React features.

results.content:
Having finished this course, I feel confident in my ability to apply React in future projects. The course is very well structured, and I highly recommend it to anyone. I like that every piece of code in the course is built from the ground up, rather than copy-pasting from snippets online. Additionally, each piece is thoroughly explained in very precise language.

Andrew does a great job of coming up with real-world examples and challenges, and finds opportunities to teach side lessons that are not only applicable to the course, but are interesting and useful otherwise.

results.content:
Andrew is by far the best instructor I have had thus far, for any of the programming courses I have taken. I am actually surprised I don't hear his name mentioned more often. 

The only negative I could possibly say is that I wish I had more free time to sit and take in his wonderfully dense course (I believe this one clocks in at 30+ hours), instead I can only devote an hour or two a day. 

If you are new to React, I would tell you to look no further than this course. Once you complete it you will have a solid understanding of all the core concepts of React (and Redux), and will be ready to start building your own applications. This course is easily worth 10X what I paid for it. 

Thank you Andrew. You put a lot of time and  effort into this, and it shows.

results.content:
I have already completed Andrew's GraphQL course which has been very useful to me now that I'm working on a graphql project at work.  I had no hesitation in signing up for this React course.  Andrew's courses are very comprehensive and he explains everything he is doing very clearly - the 'how' and the 'why'.  The exercises are essential - that's where the real learning takes place.  The early lectures are pretty quick and I could complete several in an evening, but it does get more in depth and around lecture 100, it was taking me a good couple of hours to work conscientiously through each one.  Andrew gives links to the documentation for key areas like React and Redux and I do recommend taking an evening out to go through these if you begin to lose the plot.  Nothing too difficult so far, but it's a lot of information to absorb.

Around lecture 105, I recommend taking a couple of hours to review what we've done in the Expenses application and how all the components, actions, props and state fit together.

Just like the other courses I've taken from Andrew, this one was a home run! Andrew's explanations were very thorough, his speech was easy to understand (even at 1.5x or 2x speed, which I prefer), and I really love that he includes testing in his courses. This is truly a giant topic to try covering in one course... but I feel like he pulled it off extremely well.  HIGHLY recommended if you're wanting to dive into React + Redux for web development use!

*Note:  I am actually late in writing this review... because I forgot to write one when I finished. (Sorry Andrew!) It's been several months since I took this course, but to this day I am still using LOTS of things learned from this course on a daily basis.

results.content: Excellent course overall, well presented and nicely structured. The only sticking point for me was that new features (Hooks, context...) are an add on at the end of the course as opposed to being built-in, and the main content is slightly dated. Following along using up-to-date npm packages was a bit of a challenge sometimes, although you could argue this adds to the learning process! All in all thoroughly recommended.

results.content:
Wow. After two and a half months I just finished this course and I have to say that this is the best course I've ever taken in my life. Andrew does a fantastic job of breaking down complex topics into small, understandable fragments that continually build upon and reinforce each other. The concepts were explained so well that I not only feel as though I have a better knowledge of React, but of computer programming in general.

To say that this course is JUST about React is an incredible understatement. I demo'd two other React courses before this and while they were good this course goes in depth on JSX, React, Webpack, Redux, unit testing, Firebase, and even good CSS/SCSS practices. Andrew will introduce you to concepts you never would have even thought to explore on your own and that afterwards you realize you can't live without. Overall, the difference between this course and other React courses is like the difference between an employer that just pays you and an employer that actually invests in you. You leave not only with the knowledge you came for, but a deep and tangible feeling of accomplishment.

The time and money I spent doing this course couldn't have been spent better any other way.

results.content:
Why 3 starts?

- Switching between files all the time is unnecessary. Switch to this file, run babel again, switch again and run babel again. WHY? Comments are better option, to switch between tasks (even in demonstration purposes). It disturbs workflow sooooo much. 

- please, be aware of the same names of arrays, variables, where you can be confused to read something like this:

(its an example)

let options = this.options.options.length(option) =>{
more options.option here
} 
WHY? I am sooo confused.

- please, do not focus on typing something into a string like:
 
'This is first string I have ever made in my life and I am very proud of it because I am a beginner and I want to learn as much as I can from this course'.

People gonna handle it. It's just time eater. Focus on HOW it works instead of focus on fancy looking typos in a string.

results.content:
Anytime I see Rob Percival's name on a course my immediate reaction is to avoid it like the plague.

I regret waiting so long to enroll in this one though. Andrew Mead does an amazing job of teaching not only how but why! He reinforces the topics covered with lot's of challenges. 

His teaching style is a little bit slow sometimes but some people may find that helpful. I just tend to use a faster speed setting. He speaks clearly and the audio quality is good. The video quality is solid and the content is up-to-date.

I can't speak on behalf of his responsiveness to questions asked in the Q&A because he's done such a great job of explaining things.

results.content:
This course will teach you what I think would be the correct way of building React apps. It starts slowly with the basics of React and introduces more and more tools as time goes on.  In the end you will have two React apps and a boilerplate for your future apps.

I had no real experience with React prior to this course and I learned a lot. If you are an experienced React dev I think you can safely skip this but for everyone else it's great. In case you struggle during the course, try to stick to it until the end, it will be worth it.

If you have taken Andrew's other courses, you know what to expect. Explanations are clear and I think the pace is just right. No copying code from off screen and skipped explanations here. Definitely one of the best instructors I've found on Udemy.

So if you want to delve into React, this is an amazing course to take.

results.content:
I had purchased Andrews first React Development course and enjoyed it for a while, but somewhere along the way, I began to get a bit bored. 

Seeing he released a second course and based on how much I did originally enjoy the first I thought I may as well try this one out too, and I can say I'm so glad I did, this course is much more enjoyable. The topics I feel are covered in more detail and I'm learning things I missed from his first course. 

His style of teaching is great, and he explains things very clearly. I also like the challenges he provides, he did this in his first course however I feel like the challenges he sets out in this course are much better suited to teaching the topic covered in whatever video is being watched.

--- Half way update ---

I'm now half way through the course and so far, it has been very educational. I've even started my own project using what I've learnt so far referencing the videos whenever theres a concept I forget how to properly implement.

The Redux section is quite dry compared to the rest of what I have done however I believe that is due to the nature of redux, which is quite a complex concept. Hopefully it picks back up when integrating redux within a React application. I'm most looking forward to finishing the redux section so I can begin adding it to my personal project.

results.content:
A 5-star quality course through-and-through.

Presentation style that puts student first (humility from a teacher is underrated - as opposed to "look it's so easy!" when it really isn't, Andrew really knows how to explain things thoroughly to a beginner).

In fact, one could use Andrew's teaching style it as a blueprint for 5-star 'complete', beginner-oriented courses and not go wrong. I am sure to instant-buy any of his future courses that are relevant to my interests.

results.content: Ive come back to this course twice due to time constraints. First time I couldn't get past the third section without asking for help after following direction to the T. I'm back to refresh and I found I ran into he same problem. This time I consulted the file download so I can move forward. The files are outdated and don't reflect updates in the videos so those are useless. So unless you ask for help you're stuck and can't move forward. Frustrating. What I would suggest is giving the user the ability to bypass the initial setup by using a tool like "https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app". This way you can get on w learning React and not get stuck trying to set it up.

results.content:
So far an excellent course. No black boxes, all explained as it should be.

Edit: After half-way through the course, I've decided to edit the review somewhat. Reason: a couple months later I'm still finding myself only halfway through, while having learned relatively less than on other courses. A lot of time seems to be spent on chatter and very basic code and I find myself effectively skipping large parts of the videos to find the meat of the lesson.
I will however reiterate that the main impression taken from this course is that Andrew has done a tremendous job recording his knowledge and covers a lot of ground. His teaching style is also extremely friendly and positive which stands out before many other courses so the course is still a strong recommend.

results.content:
I *really* liked this guy's Node course and struggled a little with this one. There's lots of good parts in this course and it does feel like it provided a solid foundation, in the sense that I now have much more of an understanding of the fundamentals of React/Redux than I did before the course. That said, I had a few really fundamental issues with the course:

1. As others have pointed out, it's riddled with small dependency issues. I didn't feel like this ruined my experience as much as others seem to, but it's worth noting that you'll have to do some digging through documentation on some npm modules, which isn't inherently bad, but probably shouldn't be necessary.
2. There's a lot of unnecessary material. I hadn't used Firebase before and did appreciate an intro to the tool. However, I think it figures a little too prominently, particularly for those of us familiar with more fully-tooled databases or who might be trying to combine this course with node/express/mongo. There's also like 30% too much material on testing/jest/enzyme (even though testing is very important!).
3. The teaching style too often follows a pattern of "do things using method A, now forget everything you know about method A because we're going to replace that with method B". To some extent, this is necessary in a course like this as we grow our knowledge base and things grow in complexity, but it gets very tiring at a certain point to have concepts introduced and then discarded at the rate that they are. It leaves me both a little confused about what is best practice and feeling like I've wasted a lot of time.
4. This is probably the most important point, but the material in the course is a little out of date, and I didn't realize that until the end. I do recognize the difficulty of trying to put together an extensive course on a technology that's rapidly changing, but my understanding from section 19 and a good amount of outside research is that many of the paradigms taught earlier in the course are a little outdated after the introduction of Hooks (which are helpfully, but briefly, covered at the end). I'm a little torn about how much time is spent discussing Babel/Webpack and templating an application with custom build setup only to have CRA introduced at the end. I *do* think it's important to understand how these tools work, but it requires an inordinate amount of focus at the beginning of the course, which could be better spent understanding the fundamentals of React, or Redux, etc. I think those sections would make more sense towards the end of the course, or introduced with the second project, using CRA with the first.

Overall, if you have unlimited time, this will provide a solid foundation in the tools is covers, but it sucks to take a course this long and learn that a lot of what you learned was outdated. I *highly* recommend this course/teacher if and when the course material is updated, but I might hold out until then.

Andrew is hands down the best teacher I have come across in any MOOC platform. This is the second course made by him that I complete (the other being the Node.js one) and it surpassed my expectations.

- Super knowledgable and engaging;
- Covers every topic you'd expect to be covered in a "Complete Developer Course" and brings in concepts that are not necessarily under the scope of React but which are super useful to understand what's under the hood and are handy for any web developer in general;
- Lots of exercises to practice what you are learning so that the information you are getting actually sticks. Solutions are clear and concise.

The only improvement are I can think of might be increasing the average difficulty of the exercises, which are sometimes a bit too easy as most can be solved by copying what was done in the lesson. Alternatively, there could be an optional harder exercise at the end of each chapter even if not accompanied by video.

Other than that, solid 5/5.

results.content: An amazing course, not only is React covered but a lot of other content too and Andrew is excellent at explaining how things work together. I have dropped half a star because I think, even though the Redux and React Redux sections are 6 hours, there almost feels a lack of adequate detail or there is insufficient explanation for how certain things fit into the big picture; which is not how Andrew tends to be, he usually does a great job of explaining the big picture, so it feels like a couple of small but important balls were dropped in these sections. I plan to go over them again, but I felt it was a lot of "go here and type this" instead of explaining why, but only in those sections. Everything else: stellar. Note to all new students: Redux is a bit of a steep learning curve. Don't rush it, and keep constant reminders in the back of your mind as to what you have done already or else you will soon forget where you started.

results.content:
Very informative, best course that actually explains everything with regards to React (without using the React CLI tool to create a boilerplate template). You will get to know the React tool and how it works.

There are some areas where it does get confusing, but if you rewatch or do your own learning and experiments with React, it will all click into place.

I like the fact that Andrew has some challenges for you to complete on your own before you see how he tackles the challenges problems. It is a really great way to see if you understand a topic.

This is a no-brainer and a must have course for both beginners and intermediate users.

Very informative, best course that actually explains everything with regards to React (without using the React CLI tool to create a boilerplate template). You will get to know the React tool and how it works.

There are some areas where it does get confusing, but if you rewatch or do your own learning and experiments with React, it will all click into place.

I like the fact that Andrew has some challenges for you to complete on your own before you see how he tackles the challenges problems. It is a really great way to see if you understand a topic.

This is a no-brainer and a must have course for both beginners and intermediate users.

results.content:
This course is AMAZING. Not only for its contents but also for the instructor who really cares about the students. I speak Spanish and I had no problem understanding, he is so clear. I think the best about this course is that you build real apps, going through the whole process, step by step. I think is very important that we - as developers - understand what we are doing, why we are doing it and most importantly how things work! Andrew always goes to the documentation/references and shows you where you can learn more on your own. Also the test coverage is great!

- BEGINNERS: this course is for you, you never get stucked because Andrew goes through every step with you. And if you get stucked because you missed something, or something in your code is not working, you can write in Q&A and you will get help almost immediately!
- ADVANCED: If you like more advanced courses this is good for you too because Andrew will tell you what he is going to do next, and when you can skip parts if you feel something is too easy for you.

Thank you so much!! I'm exited to build my own app now!

results.content: I watched this entire course from start to finish and completed every challenge. I can honestly say this is best the best course I've ever watched. I usually buy courses and get 50% completed with them but this course was very entertaining and helpful all the way through. This course taught me a lot of stuff I didn't know at first and taught me a new framework that I could put on my resume for future jobs. I feel very comfortable with knowing React and creating test suites with jest and enzyme. I feel ok with Webpack. It's a lot of taking In and understanding so I still need to read up on some more of that and Babel but for the most part. For the most part. This course is extremely good and I would recommend this to anyone who is starting out and want to learn React. It did its job and taught me React which I understand now. Andrew Mead is a really good instructor. One of the best in my book along with Colt and Stephen. He did what he said he would do and was helpful the whole way with answering any questions I had within 24 hours. Extremely impressive and I forever thank him. As I'm done with the course now. I have a good understanding of React to start new projects and build up my GitHub and portfolio. The 1-month journey was long but It was worth it when I look at it then and now where I'm at in my life. Thank you so much Andrew Mead and much love to you.

results.content:
It starts out pretty well. Easy to follow. But you know those learning to draw an owl courses. First a circle, then another circle. And the next step is a superrealistic owl. 
This course is a lot like that. 
Another thing I didn't like is the use of Yarn instead of NPM create-react-app. Hours are spend unnecessarily. Only interesting if you want to learn that stuff in stead of creating something creative. Also a lot of problems arise when using both. 
So after a while my project wasn't working. So I needed the resource project you can download. But that comes also with a ton of errors. Which I had to address error after error.  
And that's my last negative. The end result is literally a todo-list and a financial app. Nobody is using that. Spreadsheet and software like it are developed since the beginning of computers. We have a billion programs and apps already. I know, it's less about the app and more about learning. But really... this is boring. I think it's a problem with a lot of similar coding courses. The result is a lot of people creating a lot of similar crappy apps that won't be used and don't add anything to the world. 
I do like the way the CSS part is done. And the instructor speaks really clear.

results.content:
The course is great.

But...

I can't confirm with the updating method that just adding video clips into the original video. Andrew should know that package dependency is a huge problem with a complex project.

If you finish this course without any updating, that's great! But if you go through the course and disturbed by the "Andrew from future", it's a really bad experience.

I got a messy concept due to the unmatured updating. So as the resources with certain updating. (I mean that you update the video but do not update the resources. Sometimes you update the resources but ignore the resources after that course. What I mean is that you may update the resources in no. 150 but the resources in no. 180 is still the old one.

I think that a better way to update or add new contents is to record a new video just like Tim or Stephen Grider does.

results.content:
I bought 3 ReactJS courses.  This was the best of the 3.

Pros:
- the teacher is a polished presenter
- it is obvious the course was well thought out; not just thrown together
- concepts are presented in a logical manner, building on each other sensibly, in small steps 
- the pace is not too fast
- you get the feeling the teacher is a true expert, but knows how to make content approachable to beginners

Perhaps my favorite thing about this course is that when it is time to code, it literally begins with a blank text file.

Con:
There is only one so far.  The teacher says something early on to the effect of "ReactJS has almost no learning curve".  That made me feel a little dumb, later on, when I struggled with some of the concepts.

I am going to seek out other courses from this talented instructor!

PS: I feel bad I am only giving it 4.5 stars (which amazingly will drag it down, because it is so high ranked!) but that is jut because 5.0 means to me "perfect".  I am the type of person that can't give anything a perfect rating (unless it was God-like), but let's just say this is the best course I have seen in the 6 or 7 I have purchased. Best by far.
results.content_html:
I bought 3 ReactJS courses. This was the best of the 3.

Pros:
- the teacher is a polished presenter
- it is obvious the course was well thought out; not just thrown together
- concepts are presented in a logical manner, building on each other sensibly, in small steps
- the pace is not too fast
- you get the feeling the teacher is a true expert, but knows how to make content approachable to beginners

Perhaps my favorite thing about this course is that when it is time to code, it literally begins with a blank text file.

Con:
There is only one so far. The teacher says something early on to the effect of "ReactJS has almost no learning curve". That made me feel a little dumb, later on, when I struggled with some of the concepts.

I am going to seek out other courses from this talented instructor!

PS: I feel bad I am only giving it 4.5 stars (which amazingly will drag it down, because it is so high ranked!) but that is jut because 5.0 means to me "perfect". I am the type of person that can't give anything a perfect rating (unless it was God-like), but let's just say this is the best course I have seen in the 6 or 7 I have purchased. Best by far.

results.content:
受講開始直後

私は、COUSERAやEDXで、JAVAやC/C++の学習を数年間続けてきました。それがベースとなって、このコースの学習に、役だっていると思います。
それが無ければ。どこまでわかる事ができるだろうかとは、思います。
私の今の状態を、初心者の出発点とすれば、出発点から一つ一つ豊富な訓練を与えてくれるコースのように思えます。
このコースのレベルは、初級レベルとの事ですが、上級者のレベルまで及んでいると言われたなら、疑問を抱かない程のクオリティーを感じます。

受講終了時

ビデオレクチャーに従って、自分でコードを入力して受講を続けてきましたが、途中から、ビデオ通りには動かなくなりました。繰り返しの反復学習が必要でしょう。現場のビジネスで必要とされる事は、すべて、このコースに網羅されていると言う事でしょうか?それとも、更に次のステップに進まなければならないのでしょうか?

完全な初心者の立場として、何を習得しなけばならないかを、教えてもらったと思っています。

results.content:
I have finally completed this course after a few months with sporadic break periods. The delivery of the course is excellent - technically everything is perfect - audio/video are spot on. The course has obviously been incredibly well planned out prior to release, and there are no periods of silence/"uuum"s etc. Andrew is a very engaging teacher whose passion really comes through in his teaching style. 

Of the 2 projects created during the course, the second is by far the more difficult with a lot of additions such as redux, firebase, SCSS, testing etc. This definitely isn't a "go through it once" course. While it is challenging, everything is covered in detail. At no point during the course did I have trouble understanding the material being taught, the only problems I had were due to forgetting previous sections due to the vastness of content. 

As someone who has spent a fair amount of money and time on Udemy learning web development, this course is one of my favorites, and I would recommend it without hesitation.

results.content:
Why I'm glad I took this course.  Andrew does a great job of teaching the basics of both React and Redux but he also delivers so much more.  No front-end 'dev to deploy' stone is left unturned, he covers it all.  I completed the course a while ago and now in the process of completing other projects, I find myself revisiting many sections for reference. Whether it be for proper react and redux code patterns, testing, an example of integrating a 3rd party component,  styling with scss, initial setup and understanding of webpack , preparing webpack and code base for production and deploy, handling environments between dev-test-prod-deploy, Firebase integration and data validation,  etc.  

I've not felt the need to comment on courses I've taken online before but here it fits.  Andrew hats off to your obvious efforts on both level of detail and scope of course.  Completing and having access to your course kinda feels like having 'react dev' money in the bank.

results.content: Andrew has released his best course yet! I've taken his React 1.0 course, Node 2.0 course, and Meteor course.  Each course just gets better, but this one is really exciting. He starts off with a very simple React setup and explains some of the newer ES6 features, so the learning curve is really not too steep. If you're familiar with JavaScript, this is a great way to get into React, a popular front-end framework.

results.content:
Great course! I have given a go at learning React and Redux before and it didn't take. This course is far more in depth than my past efforts, which is really clearing a lot of the fog in my understanding (especially with Redux). And the hooks update was a welcome addition. I look forward to future updates as new features are rolled out.

I think this is a must-have course if your understanding of React/Redux is still tenuous. I definitely wish I would have started off here.

results.content: This is a course that will put anyone on the right path to learning how create React app from scratch. As you go through the course and learn a new aspect of making an app with React you are challenged to apply what you have learned. This is where the value of this course comes in because you get to use your new skill as you learn and if you fail the first time you can always go over the lessons until you get it right. It doesn't have all answers but Andrew Mead points you to some of the many resources that can help you to make your React apps on your own.

results.content:
Great course, great instructor! I found the pace of the course to be perfect - not too easy, not too difficult. New concepts were introduced in isolation and then merged into one of two larger projects that were expanded on throughout the entire course. 

Questions were answered promptly in the Q&A and any technical or version changes in software packages were addressed in small updates throughout. 

Would easily recommend to others - And I will be looking for other courses taught by Andrew in the future.

results.content: The only course to get you going for react. I loved how the basics of React were covered in the class. redux was explained  thoroughly. App testing was also good, it felt like it was done  for this app rather than learning it. Also, the boilerplate that is being created takes alot of time, in the beginning it is okay use the webpack for learning purposes, but using create-react-app would have been better. I know that Andrew thought about create-react-app, i read it in the Q&A. This course should have bigger exercises to work with than the exercises in the course like small projects. lastly, a handout or pdf guide would be great for extra help to the student like other courses of Andrew Mead. I know, the review sort of looks like a suggestion page rather than appreciation. Oh, i forgot to mention about firebase. it was great also it didn't know that it works with redux like that. Anyways thumbs Up.

results.content: I took Udacity's Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree about three years ago and learned a great deal from it. Since then I really haven't touched Javascript, and now that I need to make a web application, I was quite lost. What in the world is Webpack, Babel, and React? And how does everything fit together? Andrew's course has answered many of my questions and more. If you are disciplined and self-motivated, you will gain a great deal from this course. If you aren't, then you're missing out.

Very nice and clean course to follow with great explanations on particular aspects of React.

It needs a section about Server-Side Rendering (SSR), for example using NextJS.

Cheers.

results.content:
I learned React/Redux simultaneously about 2 years ago. The two were married in my mind so deeply that I didn't know how to use React without Redux. I picked up this course to fix that problem and to learn about Hooks since word on the street is that Redux is going to lose to Hooks in the future.

20% in and I have a much deeper understanding of React despite using it for 2 years already. I didn't expect to learn so much.

Once again, Andrew's lessons have blown me away. Wherever you are in your own development cycle, I'm confident you'll get something out of this course. Even for the parts that I can mindlessly type out, I've kind of forgotten WHY I do them the way I do them, so it's nice to have Andrew's voice in my ear reminding me of that.

results.content:
I have been learning React for close to a year now and I haven't found anything that comes remotely close to Andrews course. 

So many instructors start writing code very fast with little explanation which is counterintuitive to learning. 

Andrew carefully explains complex concepts and topics in a way that is easy to understand.
Constant lecturing is so boring. This course is not that. You are challenged with projects and follow up challenges every step of the way. This is the best way to learn in my opinion. 

The order of which topics are presented in this course is phenomenal. Almost every concept is taught in the perfect order to build on top of previous lessons. I plan on rewatching this course entirely.

The only problem I ran into were versions of packages later on in the course. I had to figure out workarounds to get my projects to run at times. This is not the instructor's fault (3rd party packages can be altered and become incompatible with one another) but it can be frustrating. 

Needles to say, Well done Andrew! Thank you for making this course!

results.content:
A good and detailed course, however I got lost at lecture 61. The amount of reworking the example Indecision app became too confusing to follow and I found I was just typing along.  I have done all the challenges up to and including section 7. There doesn't seem to be a linear progression in building the app, it jumps from one technique to another when a new tool is introduced and code is then removed and reworked. The configurations of Babel, Webpack are done in good detail but the example app is overly reworked. I get the instructor is trying to demonstrate how to turn a monolithic codebase into smaller files and installing tools along the way. The problem is side-tracking to tools and returning to the code and reworking it depending on the tool just installed is exhausting and just too confusing to be able to flow along smoothly. Its far better to get all the tools in place and introduce different techniques with simple examples and then build the app with the final preferred technique in one continuous series of videos. By the time I got through section 6, Webpack, I'd lost the flow of the code on the example app in section 7. Probably section 6 and 7  should be looked at again I found after the whole WebPack section I had lost my thread on the concepts learnt in the earlier sections, especially and critically about passing state and communications between components. It's a really detailed course but in some places maybe moves too fast where the instructor could spend more time to reinforce concepts and maybe labours too much on details that soon become reworked and redundant.

UPDATE: I have decided to continue and persevere with the course and completed Part 1. of the course the first example App, which I feel good about and have increased the rating to 4.5. 
I actually went and bought another React course but decided that one was not for me so abandoned it and came back to this one.
UPDATE 2
I have now got to video lecture 107. Since my last review the course has stepped up a notch and gone into Redux, state management, touched on regular expressions and a whole lot of other stuff. I have mostly followed along but got lost in a couple of the challenges. What I'm still struggling with is the syntax. most of my errors are missing curly braces or using brackets where there should be braces or missing brackets and semi-colons. I've actually supplemented a pure javascript course to help with those issues and get more practice with the syntax. The styling Indecision example app was nice and gave a sense of achievement. The Higher order component was a little confusing not in concept but in syntax and figuring out how to work it. I think once the whole project is completed it may be easier to sit back and review it in its entirety and see how it all hangs together. At the moment its like making a jigsaw without the end picture but it's getting there. Some of the section 11,  20 min videos have taken me an hour to get through just because of a small typo I made in the challenge or whilst typing along to the lecture and then trying to fix that as well as trying to understand the concept.
UPDATE: 
I just completed section 11, I say completed but I actually gave up trying to follow along coding by the final video in the section. The content was moving too fast, too confusing and way too much to take onboard for a single video trying to build on top of many new concepts already. The whole example application is way too complex to learn with, adding dates into the mix and a third party library makes this project large and I find myself getting lost in details and moving away from the objective which is to understand react. It was the same pattern with the first example which became too confusing. Just slow it down and be really clear on what is being developed and the interactions between the codebase. The course is good to learn  tooling and even javascript syntax but the project is not great to follow along, too big and unwieldy, lots of effort to get small results. In the final video there were not even any challenges as it was way too complex. I think the intention from the instructor was there but the execution becomes clearly too involved as teaching material unless you are willing to go over a whole bunch of videos again and review the code to figure it all out if you have the time, which I would if I felt I would properly learn but I don't think I will, I'm struggling to keep up typing along and listening to audio trying to figure out the context of what is being taught.
I think I'm going to park this course at Section 11.
results.content_html:
A good and detailed course, however I got lost at lecture 61. The amount of reworking the example Indecision app became too confusing to follow and I found I was just typing along. I have done all the challenges up to and including section 7. There doesn't seem to be a linear progression in building the app, it jumps from one technique to another when a new tool is introduced and code is then removed and reworked. The configurations of Babel, Webpack are done in good detail but the example app is overly reworked. I get the instructor is trying to demonstrate how to turn a monolithic codebase into smaller files and installing tools along the way. The problem is side-tracking to tools and returning to the code and reworking it depending on the tool just installed is exhausting and just too confusing to be able to flow along smoothly. Its far better to get all the tools in place and introduce different techniques with simple examples and then build the app with the final preferred technique in one continuous series of videos. By the time I got through section 6, Webpack, I'd lost the flow of the code on the example app in section 7. Probably section 6 and 7 should be looked at again I found after the whole WebPack section I had lost my thread on the concepts learnt in the earlier sections, especially and critically about passing state and communications between components. It's a really detailed course but in some places maybe moves too fast where the instructor could spend more time to reinforce concepts and maybe labours too much on details that soon become reworked and redundant.

Andrew is very clear and descriptive going through how to both implement React, as well as building the store for Redux. If you are looking to learn or get into React with Redux then this is the course to start with. Even with the new API changes for context in React since v16.3 earlier in the year (I think it's on 16.5 now?) this course is still absolutely relevant and will help get you started and direct you on where to go so you can continue.

Four thumbs up!

results.content:
I went through other React courses/tutorials just to get different perspectives/coding styles and found this course to be far superior to any of the others I've been through.

Andrew is excellent at keeping things simple while exploring a complex topic. He also is very unassuming with your prior knowledge or skill (he explains little details that other instructors simply gloss over or skip entirely).

This course contains everything you need to get started with React/Redux and feel confident in building your own applications with best practice approaches.

 - i know that's a pretty new feature, but i think that the course needs to be more focused on using hooks then redux.

-redux is a design pattern, i think it would be great if you'd use some simple diagrams to simplify this one, and other patterns learned.
thank you !

results.content:
This is a great React course and the instructor, Andrew, really does great work with his courses.  He not only gives an excellent in-depth review and walk-through of React, but he does deep dives into important concepts along the way, like ES6 classes, arrow functions, and variable declarations.

I took Andrew's original course on React and it was good, but it was prior to React 13, and so the course used some methods and functions that weren't as relevant today.  While I was mostly interested in just updating my existing applications, I decided it would be worth it to brush up on what's changed and the standard way of building React applications.  So far, I am glad that I did.  The previous course was great, but now over 18 months later, not only have we moved on from ES5, we've moved well into ES6 and starting to imagine the future of JavaScript, and so the new course is focused squarely on that.  Beyond that, the course has indepth overviews of Redux, which had been gaining momentum when I went through the last course, but now is the most popular state management store for React applications.

Andrew presents everything with high energy, and I'm always surprised he can keep momentum and energy up through each video because it must be a slog to product 35+ hours of video, especially with extra takes.  Beyond that, he is clear and concise in descriptions, and because I was familiar with a lot of the early content, I was able to set the talking speed to 2x and not miss anything.

The course structure is good as well, with most videos introducing a concept, doing some co-development, and then challenging the student to implement a similar feature in their sandbox.  Finally, we the end of each section, a larger challenge is presented requiring the student to go back and implement concepts that might have been from earlier in the course.  This can be challenging at times, and I'll think to myself, "Hm, I kinda know how to do that, but we haven't covered this yet..." which prompts me to go back and review what we had covered (just the summaries), and then it jogs my memory and prompts me to implement something in a way that I wouldn't have previously done.

I'm mid-way through the course now and really pleased with how it's going, so I'm interested in completing it.  Overall, I think this is an excellent way to learn React and Andrew does a great job with it.
results.content_html:

results.content:
For someone experienced in react but wanted a recap on foundations, it would be nice to have all the "summaries" bookmarked automatically (rather than rely on users) so we can just go to the summary.

Then, if we don't know about the topic, we can watch it from the beginning.

Short lessons (<10min) are good to help retention. I find myself playing everything on 2x because of the verbiage (too drawn out... sometimes redundant). If explanations were more succinct that would be more efficient in my case.

Redux stuff was really good! Also walked through stuff that I hate doing like webpack and babel. Good to know, but so much extra details that doesn't really add to the content.

results.content:
I picked this up on a sale and honestly didn't expect much, as I was already enrolled in a Nanodegree at Udacity for Frontend Web development. I figured I'd grab this video series and listen to it in the background to hear how someone else explains the React content that Udacity had taught me.

After all, I'm paying $200 a month for Udacity, and this was only $11, so there's no way this could provide more value, right?

Yeah, I was wrong. I soon saw just how much detail this got into. I skipped over some of the intro to react and JS stuff but there is just so much here for intermediate developers new to React that this went from being an auxiliary resource to being my main source of training. 

I'm working on my final project for my Nanodegree and I'm taking this course to make it awesome and include all the stuff Udacity didn't teach me, like Redux, Firebase, and just the great file patterns Andrew shows. 

I learned about the basics of react-router from Udacity, but I learned how to really implement it and how to structure my files from this course.

results.content: First of all this rating in no way reflects how I feel about Andrew Mead.  He, hands down is one of the best instructors on Udemy.  However, I invested a lot of time in this course and as more of these libraries get updated they tend to break other libraries that share dependencies.  Ultimately, you will be left with a giant mess that is really hard to cleanup.  I am a long time programmer (not with modern frameworks like this though), so I am not afraid to chase solutions when things break, but you get to a point of diminishing return and that is where I wound up on this course.  75% through it, unable to complete it.  If the course ever gets updated I might restart or retake it simply because I truly enjoy Andrew's teaching style and his depth of knowledge.  But folks, this course is way out of date now and installing these old versions of React and the multitude of other stuff is not going to  be good.  Plus newer versions of webpack, hooks, and react itself are easier to deal with for getting up and running.  Still a pain though for sure.  I hope someday React and the community supporting it can get to a stable version and hang there for long enough for me to get through a course :)
results.content_html: First of all this rating in no way reflects how I feel about Andrew Mead. He, hands down is one of the best instructors on Udemy. However, I invested a lot of time in this course and as more of these libraries get updated they tend to break other libraries that share dependencies. Ultimately, you will be left with a giant mess that is really hard to cleanup. I am a long time programmer (not with modern frameworks like this though), so I am not afraid to chase solutions when things break, but you get to a point of diminishing return and that is where I wound up on this course. 75% through it, unable to complete it. If the course ever gets updated I might restart or retake it simply because I truly enjoy Andrew's teaching style and his depth of knowledge. But folks, this course is way out of date now and installing these old versions of React and the multitude of other stuff is not going to be good. Plus newer versions of webpack, hooks, and react itself are easier to deal with for getting up and running. Still a pain though for sure. I hope someday React and the community supporting it can get to a stable version and hang there for long enough for me to get through a course :)

I started out thinking this course was really good, however I think there are some major flaws
.
I don't think there should be so much focus throughout on constantly using the shorthand way of writing every bit of code. If you're just starting out, at least in my opinion as a beginner, I think the most important thing is really being able to understand the data flow. results.content:
I think the course was fantastic overall, and that Andrew is one of the best instructors on this platform (I'd even go as far as to say one of the best I've ever had).

A few small recommendations:
1) I'd place greater emphasis on security when it comes to API keys. I feel like putting the deployment section before covering environment variables for firebase could lead to students publishing their keys with little thought.

2) In firebase, the default database is set to something other than "Realtime DB" by default. It might be worth a quick update to point this out to students.

3) It should be mentioned that NoSQL solutions aren't always the best tool for the job, especially when dealing with relational data. Personally, I liked the firebase section because it helped to expand my familiarity with NoSQL offerings, but for a new student this might be a detrimental choice.

4) It might be good to add a video or two on containerizing the expensify app prior to deployment on Heroku.
results.content_html:
I think the course was fantastic overall, and that Andrew is one of the best instructors on this platform (I'd even go as far as to say one of the best I've ever had).

A few small recommendations:
1) I'd place greater emphasis on security when it comes to API keys. I feel like putting the deployment section before covering environment variables for firebase could lead to students publishing their keys with little thought.

2) In firebase, the default database is set to something other than "Realtime DB" by default. It might be worth a quick update to point this out to students.

3) It should be mentioned that NoSQL solutions aren't always the best tool for the job, especially when dealing with relational data. Personally, I liked the firebase section because it helped to expand my familiarity with NoSQL offerings, but for a new student this might be a detrimental choice.

4) It might be good to add a video or two on containerizing the expensify app prior to deployment on Heroku.

Thanks Mr Mead.

Great course, with a wonderful instructor. I would highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in current web development. 

There are a few things that it would have been nice to have, though. Some such things are quizzes, Section summaries, additional reading material and resources, but I feel that the course is well worth anyone's time. It does rely on some prerequisite knowledge, but I feel as though without it, you will still be able to follow through this course, but you will have to learn certain things as you go.

results.content:
This was an outstanding course!

The instructor, Andrew J Mead, is very methodical and excellent at explaining each and every topic from a "this is why it is done this way" approach with examples and then ultimately explaining "the easy way" later.

I find that from my personal learning experiences that a topic sticks with me longer if I know the reasoning behind why something is done a certain way first, I.e., learn the "why" and then the "how".  Andrew presents nearly all of the topics in the course this way.

Because Andrew is so thorough in his explanations, this course is quite long and in the end the two example apps are not very extensive in their capabilities.  However each component of the application is thoroughly explained from basic principles to the final implementation.

I was also extremely impressed with how quickly Andrew or one of his assistants (Adam) responded to my questions.  Typical response time was within a matter of a few hours and it never took even a day before I received a reply.  This team has been more responsive than any other team from any of the 90+ Udemy courses that I own!  I really appreciated hearing directly from Andrew; out of all of my questions, Andrew responded over 50% of the time!

Thank you Andrew and Adam for providing such an excellent course and for being so responsive with the Q&A!

Jeff Moritz

This course is fantastic, and the only reason that I didn't give it a full 5 stars is because of the instances - mostly related to configuration setup - where I felt lost and wasn't clear on why certain things had to be done. Although at the end of the course we have a template in which we mostly don't have to worry too much about changing configuration settings, it would be nice if more time were spent on understanding the fundamentals around it.

Otherwise, the course was very educational, and now I feel confident in my ability to build my own web app.

results.content:
Very concise and well explained content. Teacher has a very good pace, and knows how to teach progressively, with good challenges in almost every lesson. I'm enjoying a lot.

Update:  After completing the course, I think this is the most useful and well structured course I've applied on Udemy. 
I'm already in production mode! 

1 year after finished the course, and after have developed my own real world app, I realized that this course is not so complete as I thought. To be complete, there should have a project with, at least, more than 1 entity, to learn how to shape a redux store, how to normalize it, and how to manage the state. How to optimize the app, and others advanced topics. So, this is not a complete React Developer Cours, but a basic course. I think that if the Title of the course was changed, this should be  a 5 star. But, for a "complete course", deserves a 3.5 star.

results.content:
This is hands-down, one of the best tutorial curriculum's I've ever taken. I've been to an iOS developer boot camp, I've taken Udacity's online video course for full stack development, this course takes the top prize. 

Successful tutorials need to accomplish a few things. One, teach the basic core concepts. Two, display and test you on those core concepts as a part of a larger project. Three, have a project that you would be proud showing to your mother ;), or hiring manager. This course does it all. He starts with the basics and leads you along the entire way to completion of a sophisticated project. At the end, you have a very sophisticated web application that syncs with a backend, set up user accounts, and implements the fundamentals that you will use in every project, filtering, search, site architecture such as list and detail pages. It is a fantastic start that you can grow from.

Honestly, if you are on the fence for what is usually a $10 course on Udemy, I would have gladly paid $100 or more. I paid $500 for Udacity's full-stack developer course. With this React course, I have a portfolio ready project and understand the fundamentals to go and attack new features and tutorials and projects with ease.

This is one of the more professional curriculums I have come across. The video quality, the audio, maintenance to the course videos related to software updates, and responsiveness of Andrew and his team for when I need help to debug my code. I am in awe. Thanks, Andrew and to your team. Your excitement and knowledge shine throughout the course. I am extremely grateful that you put this together.

results.content:
Generally, I enjoyed the whole course very much. Andrew taught me a lot about React starting from the very basics up to working with async Redux and plugging Firebase in. 

The things I like the most, probably, were about structuring the whole projects- from components, scss structure, to very helpful tips about using Webpack and two different types of environment.

The one thing I lacked was in the section about async Redux. Andrew chose Redux Thunk (and that's perfectly okay), but I feel that mentioning alternative approaches (such as Redux Saga) would be benefitial.

All in all, great course! I can't wait for another one! :)
results.content_html:
Generally, I enjoyed the whole course very much. Andrew taught me a lot about React starting from the very basics up to working with async Redux and plugging Firebase in.

The things I like the most, probably, were about structuring the whole projects- from components, scss structure, to very helpful tips about using Webpack and two different types of environment.

The one thing I lacked was in the section about async Redux. Andrew chose Redux Thunk (and that's perfectly okay), but I feel that mentioning alternative approaches (such as Redux Saga) would be benefitial.

All in all, great course! I can't wait for another one! :)

results.content:
I've been working at this every single day for several hours per day for the last full month. It is an extremely in-depth course. It's way more than I thought and at times it has been frustrating to think I need to know all this stuff, but compared to the last React course I took, this one really taught me A LOT. The other one didn't teach Redux and gave the simplest bare bones instructions on how to get started with React. I would have never guessed there could be so much more to it.

I am really thankful that all of these details were included because I can't imagine how difficult it would be to research all this stuff and figure it out on my own. It simply wouldn't happen. After completing this course, I at least have a leg up on figuring out how to look at this sort of documentation. Not only does it teach React and Redux, it explains several plugins you need to do various things with React and Redux, Babel, Webpack, production and dev configurations (in excruciating detail), Heroku CLI and Git deployment, Jest testing (also in excruciating detail), modern workflow meticulously organized, even a bit of NodeJS and Express to get the React app running on Heroku (painless and helped me really distinguish what NodeJS is compared to React—at this point I think I like NodeJS better, but it's nice to know they can work together.) I want to point out that I absolutely hate Redux, despite the TA insisting it's incredibly simple once you get the hang of it.

I'm about to dive into the Firebase section next, so there's still plenty more to learn. Honestly, I probably have another week or two before I finish the course. I will need to review parts of it if I want to memorize a lot of this stuff, but if I do, then I will be well on my way to being a master not a novice.

The course is up-to-date, far more in-depth detailed and organized than any course I've ever seen (and I've taken a lot of courses).

Andrew and his TA are in the comments section every day answering questions quickly. It is surprising how attentive they are and how incredibly great the TA is at knowing exactly what the problem is and solving it quickly. It's got to be a lot to keep track of but they clearly have no problem keeping track of it.

The really good thing about this course is if you work with it every day, you will have full code immersion and you can't help but get better at Javascript. Whether or not React is what I want to get paid to do is another matter...but you can't know until you really dive into something like this, so thank you so much, Andrew Mead!

results.content: I have to say that I really, really liked this course. I've done a lot of courses on Udemy and this might have been the best. There were absolutely no shortcuts. Everything was done properly, and INCLUDING (this is very rare for dev courses) the styling of the applications. FINALLY a course that actually goes into depth on the styling and doesn't use bootstrap. I can't stand how almost every single course I find always just uses bootstrap and I don't get to see how one would actually go about writing proper SASS and how all of that integrates with the overall project. It was so refreshing to have such a clearly well-prepared and well-thought out course with an extremely competent, friendly instructor.

results.content: What a journey! I expected some crash course on React but this was so much more. Maybe a bit too much! Some parts I really had to force myself to get through, especially all the testing. It's a bit confusing at first why this is all necessary but I guess it will make sense in the long term. Anyway, I learned A LOT. Not only about React but good development practices in general! This course is very good in connecting all the dots. I completed the course in a short time to prepare for an upcoming interview and to have something nice in my portfolio. I won't say I understand everything completely but I have something to show! No, I have two projects to show: Indecision and Expensify, both made in the course. I'm very happy with that. I'm a lot more confident and can't wait to expand my knowledge and start building React apps on my own. Thank you so much Andrew!

results.content:
This is a very solid course wich covers a wide range of topics to get started with React like React-Router, ES6, Redux, setting up and configuring a Webpack development server, styling React with the SASS language, authentication with firebase and much more.

Andrew lets you doing challenges along the course which make you remember what you've actually learned.

Next to that Andrew covers a whole lecture about Test-driven development using Jest, which is a very important topic.

If you want to learn programming in React for the web including all the tools and techniques to setup and deploy a fully working application than this is the course to pick!

results.content:
Wow, what a course! I looked at a few different options for React classes and I'm glad I picked this one, it's a lot more comprehensive than the others.

There were a couple times where the course went too fast for me, but I was usually able to re-watch previous lessons, read Q&A's and research online to figure things out. 

I really liked all of the exercises that Andrew included, they helped me understand the material more than anything. And they were just the right amount of challenging.

results.content:
Too much webpack stuff.  I guess it's good to understand how webpack works, but create-react-app has been out for a while now, and no React beginner should be attempting to create their app from scratch anymore.  Now you just install create-react-app with npm and run it whenever you want to create a new, preconfigured React app.  It takes like 2 minutes, but this course has you doing a 2+ hours webpack section, plus a bunch of other stuff to get webpack working.

Also, Andrew makes a form but he doesn't use it in a controlled component.  I know you can get away with not using a controlled component so it's not 100% necessary, but it's an important part of React so that was a missed opportunity to teach people something.

Honestly, I wouldn't recommend anyone take any React course that doesn't use create-react-app, unless they specifically want to learn how to set up webpack.

Andrew confirms to be an excellent teacher.

If he does a mistake (simple typo) he says that it's normal, that everyone does mistakes, but the reality is that he pretends to do mistakes ( anyway 2-3 times during the course) just to let you feel that he is human.

He is not the teacher that the community deserves, but the one that the community needs.

results.content:
This is the best React course to take you from beginner to intermediate. 

Andrew teaches with a ton of enthusiasm. He understands pace, so he never goes on any long monologues where he just drones on conceptually about a piece of code. Instead his explanations are short and sweet, always breaking subjects down to a practical level. He shows you a piece of code, explains how we use it, then gives you a small challenge to integrate it to the application yourself. Afterwards, he'll show you the correct solution.

Andrew goes into great detail about React and Redux, starting you off with building small components to very usable applications. After completing this course, you will have a fundamental to solid understanding on React and should have the confidence to develop your own React applications.

results.content: The course is very thorough and teaches React development very well, but I felt that there were too many tangents. I am looking to learn the React library/framework and best practices, not the basics of JavaScript. Yes this is a course for beginners, but it is possible to be a beginner to React, while being an experienced JavaScript developer. The course jumps between React and JavaScript concepts. For a thorough full stack course like this, it might have been better to separate out the JavaScript into one long section followed by a long section on React, so that those of us who just want the React portion can just jump to that section.

results.content: I really like this course. Andrew is a great teacher, he explains the codes in detail and in steps to take the student along. This is great enabling one to follow what he is doing and makes complex codes clear to understand and build. He does not jump from one thing to another. He inspires me to keep learning with his enthusiasm. Which is brilliant. Andrew talks everything through, helping to cement one's understanding of the codes and makes it easier for me to follow along. Although, I found some parts of the course hard at times to grasp and retain, being completely new to React. For example, some parts of the Redux, test scripts and some challenges. Some of those took me much longer to grasp, so needed to go over those parts again (and again sometimes) to understand and get better, compared to some other sections and challenges, which I grasped straight away. Naturally, by going over and over again on those parts, I understood and got better with the codes.  Some elements of the codes are sometimes a bit harder to understand and retain so required extra work on my part to build the understanding and help get familair.  Towards the end of the course, I needed to refer to my notes at times, for some things we did at the earlier part of the course. The course is long as there are so much to learn. Notes are important. I am very happy I found this course.
