results.content:
This is a great course.

Andrew is extremely clear in explaining things, and the pace is perfect, starting with the basics of React and walking through the more complex stuff.

You get hands-on experience building two simple web apps, including using Git and eventually deploying the second one on Heroku. 

One notable thing about this course was that you are not just coding along. Andrew frequently makes you do small coding challenges, which can be stretching. Even if you can't get them and have to watch the solution, you learn much more than if you didn't do any. This gives you confidence to try things out on your own.

I feel comfortable using React now. Thanks Andrew.

results.content: Andrew's courses are great, incredibly well thought out, and his presentation is well articulated. That being said, this course would be much better if you didn't spend 35% of it writing jest cases. I understand introducing testing as it's incredibly important, especially if you've never done it before, but this is not a jest/enzyme course, it's a react/redux course. It would have been nice to have two smaller apps so that more react topics could have been addressed and executed, instead of one big app where you spend hours of time on testing. Either that or the testing should have been pulled out into its own 'recommended' section for people who wanted to learn about it so it could be avoided if you're already familiar with it. At this point it's too ingrained to skip.

results.content:
Excellent pacing, great materials, all in all, this is probably one of, if not the best, e-learning courses I have taken to date. 

The lecturer really gets down to the essentials, cuts through any jargon and just teaches you all you need to know about react concepts, setup processes, build tooling such as webpack (which is used in almost any react workflow) and so much more! 

Even as a full time frontend developer and react user on and off for a couple years, I have learned and picked up on quite a few things I hadn't realised before and so if you couldn't tell yet, I highly recommend this course to anyone looking to get into react development or to brush up on a few things like me!

results.content: Great instructor. He clearly knows the material very well & is very well spoken and organized. There are many exercises peppered throughout the videos (often more than one per video), and they are just right in terms of difficulty. The exercises form part of the application being built, so the instructor always covers their solutions in great detail. Concepts and techniques are well motivated and well explained. The instructor is also very lively, enthusiastic, and engaging, which makes watching the videos enjoyable.

results.content:
Having taken other courses from Andrew I was confident that this course wouldn't disappoint. It covers everything expected and more. Explains the basics of React very thoroughly.

The main project combines Redux and Firebase to create a neat web app. There is a great amount of emphasis explaining how to use Jest and Enzyme for Test Driven Development. Which is easy to overlook but possibly the most important part of the course. Just getting all of this software setup correctly is quite a challenge!

WebDev is constantly evolving and React is no different. It must be a challenge keep the course up to date. There is loads of support available in the Q&A section at any stage.

I particularly liked the bonus section as it provides an overview of new features in React.

Thank you Andrew.

I had no real expectations about the course before starting it, and I had no experience with React. I found React to be a really interesting tool with some powerful features.

The course itself was very well structured. The instructor started off with the basics and built up slowly. The course covers A LOT of stuff and at times it felt a little overwhelming, but with some practice it all fits in nicely.

The instructor, Andrew Mead, does a great job explaining the various topics, and the examples and use cases that are used throughout the course are simple enough to follow but also complex enough to cover all topics necessary to a React newbie.

results.content:
Let me start with positives. Andrew is nice and leads students to use the Q&A section whenever they need it.
But. In the course Andrew is using an outdated version of libraries, some of them are even deprecated. I would more appreciate it if Andrew makes a step forward and update the course with the latest libraries. I'm not saying to update course with every new minor version, but with the major it's a must for me.
The applications which are created during course are too simple, not reflecting real-world problems, also without mentioning possible performance problems. Speaking about performance problems, there is several times mention that, there is no difference between inline event handler vs. declared function ex. input onChange, but in fact, there is.
The testing in course is using "outdated" (I mean not recommended by React docs) testing frameworks (Enzyme) instead of Testing library. Speaking about testing, there is a completely missing how to test React hooks. On the other hand, the course is updated with react hooks, but without deep comparing with class-based components and function components.
Speaking about React hooks; section 19 contains comparing React hooks with life-cycle methods in React, but course doesn't cover it at all!
Also, I'm missing at least a mention about TypeScript, other webpack features, React app hierarchy, and performance optimizations.

From the Complete React developer course, I would expect more.

results.content: This is my second course of Andrew's.  He designs comprehensive courses with excellent examples that build upon each other so the student can put the concepts to work in a real life project. With this comprehensive approach the student walks away not only learning the core materials, but an equally valuable set of other useful bits.  For this course these are things like practical applications of libraries (e.g. moment), authentication, regular expressions, and database connectivity.  I also love how Andrew takes you on a path from a basic to a more advanced syntax option, providing the justification and demonstrating first in a playground file.

results.content:
This is a FAST paced class.  I know it has to be or it would take 60 hours to cover the material.  There is a wealth of useful information.  The end result is new skills and a template application that can be used for future projects.

I did get lost in the videos tying redux to firebase.  I think the problem was things just happened too fast.

The explanation of the webpack setup was very helpful.  I would not have figured out the relationship with babel, enzyme, jest, and webpack without this class.  I still don't fully understand it, but I have the template now for future projects.

The final section is something I was looking for.  He really helped me fully understand react hooks.

Andrew has a great gift for teaching!

results.content:
Just finished this course!  Whew!  Extensive, yet so informative with no details left out.
Instructor makes every piece of instruction very clear and easy to understand.  Examples are walked through at a steady pace, but one is able to keep up. The exercises on our own are great and very beneficial.  Instructor and the teacher's assistant answer questions almost as fast as they're asked, which is so refreshing to get quick insightful help when needed.  
Andrew Mead really "teaches" you when going through the videos, as opposed to just walking you through the tutorial.  I feel this video finally gave me the tools and confidence needed to make my own apps and sites for others on my own.

Thanks!

results.content:
まず、Reactは素晴らしい。
元々ActionScript3.0で仕事をしていたが、いよいよ終焉を向かえるにあたり、より直感的なフレームワークを探していた。
Vue.jsも素晴らしいアイデアを持つフレームワークだが、独創性が強すぎて直感的に構築することが難しいと判断してReactに乗り換えた。
ReactはFlashの概念と、Actionscript、Javascript、現在のWeb技術の進化系と位置づけてもよいと思うほど似ていると感じ、極めて直感的にプログラミングに集中できるフレームワークだ。
そしてAndrewは素晴らしい!
node.jsでも受講しているが、実にわかりやすく本当に人を惹きつける。
常に変化するバージョンにもいち早く対応しているし、余す所なく徹底して解説してくれる。
残念ながら日本語訳では対応されていないが、同時に英語も学習できると思えばそれも悪くないと思う。
プログラミング初心者は、基本的な知識は予め必要な内容となっている。
オブジェクト指向、Javascript基本構文、Classの概念、継承などが何かとは一切触れていない。
しかしこの講義とともに学習すれば、終了する頃には立派なエンジニアになっているだろう。サーバーサイドのnode.js、フロントサイドならReact、講師はAndrewがお勧めです。(Node.jsはかなりコードな所まで踏み込んでいます。)

results.content:
To be honest, I do not think there is a better course than this if you want to learn the React.
I started off with zero knowledge of React (I had solid knowledge of javascript), and I asked for a course to learn the React, but in this course I did not just learn the React, but I learned the React, Redux, Firebase, how to set up live with a Heroku.

Also, Andrew perfectly explains new ES6 concepts such as destructuring and spread operator and immediately shows how they can be useful.
After this course, I had a self-confidence to immediately start making my own applications.
If you want to really learn the React, you can not make a mistake with this course.

Thank you Andrew and Adam and continue with a great job!

results.content: i definitely think andrew's node course is better.  i am currently ~70% of the way through this course in april 2020 and it appears that many of the dependencies/tools/npm modules used in this course  are not compatible with the latest version of react.  this has caused issues at many points throughout the class as i try to follow along.  i feel like i am always scouring the comment section for fixes and updates to problems i run into.  i will say that adam and andrew do a good job of responding to student questions as i am always able to eventually find the updated commands to run and/or steps to take to get things working again, but it is still a very frustrating experience.  15 minute videos often end up taking 45 minutes or longer to get through.  i hope they update this course soon because andrew is a great teacher; if it weren't for all of the compatibility issues that i seem to be running into as a result of these videos being filmed in 2017, my rating for the course would be closer to a 4.5 or 5.

Having previously completed Andrew's Meteor and React course the material here is a degree of difficulty greater. However with well paced, clear and thorough presentations and carefully worked out and placed tasks the material is easily assimilated. Just one minor difficulty for someone on the other side of the Atlantic, there are some American idioms and pronunciations that need some getting used to!

results.content:
For the amount of content that's in here I really can't give this less than five stars, so that's my rating.  Additional info below to help you make a decision.

Andrew covers stuff from react v16 which is good to know.  At the end of the course you will have a boilerplate package comprised entirely of things you understand and no magic, which is great.

Near the end of the course there is extensive use of firebase.  I am not a huge fan of firebase but it simplifies authentication and authorization down to essentially one function call.  I think that was probably part of the decision to use firebase and don't let that deter you.

I would have to say though that the highlight of the course for me was the testing section which outlines some simple and effective ways to test react components.

results.content:
Pros:
- Course is very well structured. The lessons make sense and build on top of each other.
- Great in-depth explanations. It's easy to follow the course.
- The course contains many good challenges that you can always solve by yourself using what has been covered by the course up to that point.
- At the end of the course you have a usable product.

Cons:
- The course covers way too many topics that I would never have expected. If you don't know at least the basics of CSS, you really shouldn't start with React. Also, I don't think, git, Heroku or Firebase have anything to do with a React course. I understand that those tools helped show how to create an actually useful React app and deliver it to the web, but it still is a random tool stack that took up a lot of time of the course.

results.content:
Fantastic course that teaches more than just React.js! I love that it also went over Firebase to get a glimpse into how a database is setup and how to connect this with the application. I like how it also featured how to deploy your application with Git and Heroku, something that I, for no real reason, always found quite daunting to get into. Besides this, testing your application isn't something I've ever done before or seen mentioned often but I like that the course included this as well, I think it is an important and underrated tool that gets left out of courses too often.

Overall just an amazing course, just like the JavaScript course I first started out with. Quick replies on the questions as well by Adam whenever I had a question, never did I have to wait longer than a day for a response - unless it was saturday/sunday but that is to be expected haha ;)

The only complaint I have about the course is setting up the dependecies and configuring webpack and the like. I could understand why'd we implement or configure these things and I know the course is more oriented around React, but I would've wanted a bit more info on certain things like: what loaders are like the babel or the CssExtractPlugin, what environment variables are exactly before setting them all up.
Like I said, it's my only complaint and a minor one, but those parts frustrated me a bit and got me out of the 'flow'. This might only be me and could be attributed to React's negative part of setting up an entire environment and 600 dependecies (I'm glad create-react-app exists) but that's all I wanted to give my opinion on!

Anyway, thanks again for such a great course! I'll probably post a project of mine here sometime in the future!

results.content:
What I like about this course:
1. Andrew's very friendly and encouraging, instruction are well-paced, step by step, thus beginner-friendly. 
2. I LOVE those small challenges. It really helps by winning those little by little, it's better than a big lecture then you have to write a huge assignment. 
3. Section intro and summary really helps.

Improvement:
1. a lot of changes happened lately which make parts of the video out-of-date. Maybe it's useful to note the date when the video was created so students can refer to that if they want to use newer versions of things. 
2. It would be nice to have a PDF list of libraries installed, with brief description of what they do. 
3. Also nice to have more graphic high-level of explanatin, especially when it comes to difficult concept like Redux and testing. Those parts tend to be quite confusing for beginners.

results.content:
Very good course overall. I learned a lot, although I feel I'm just beginning to grasp React. It was / is a long course and it took me several weeks to finish it (time it takes will obviously depend on how much time you have to put in...). I'll admit that towards the end I was beginning to get frustrated with the length, but I kept watching the videos and doing the exercises till the end. 

The exercises the teacher gives you tend to be easy, maybe a bit too easy for someone like me who has prior programming experience. Some of the later exercises did provide some challenge, but I don't really remember getting stuck anywhere at any point. This is not to say that the exercises were useless, on the contrary, I believe they solidified the points made during teaching (which was the point I guess). It's just that personally I would've hoped for some more challenging tasks.

All in all, I do recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn building modern web apps with React and has some spare time to put in to this course. It won't turn you into a pro (just like any single course won't), but will definitely give a good foundation to build upon.

results.content:
This is a fantastic course. I took another introductory React course on Udemy and while it was good, Andrew is much better at really going into the details of what is happening. I loved that we didn't immediately jump into using create-react-app, which really abstracts away a lot of the "magic".

I am now more confident that I will be able to make my own React app from scratch.

One thing I do wish the course touched on was how to pull data from an API. While we used Firebase to accomplish saving data in the cloud, I do wish there were at least a few lectures that tried to pull data from an outside source (e.g. a way to convert the currency in the Expensify app) that we had to parse ourselves, instead of using the Firebase library to abstract away some of the http requests.

Fantastic course! Well structured, with interesting real-world projects. The pace was just right for me (previous programming experience), Andrew goes into details where needed, and guides you to places where you can read up more on a given topic.

Although it might seem a bit overwhelming at first, with all the new tools being introduced frequently, it at the same time gives you a complete toolset for building your next apps.

By the end, aside from the knowledge, you are left with a working boilerplate, ready to be used in future projects. The excersises given help in cementing the knowledge. I highly recomend this one!

Although it might seem a bit overwhelming at first, with all the new tools being introduced frequently, it at the same time gives you a complete toolset for building your next apps.

By the end, aside from the knowledge, you are left with a working boilerplate, ready to be used in future projects. The excersises given help in cementing the knowledge. I highly recomend this one!

results.content:
I have years of work experience in Python and JavaScript/jQuery and some grounding in functional languages so the concepts introduced in the course are very familiar. However, I am found myself asking questions and having those questions being answered shortly afterwards in the course which is a great sign of both course design/flow and also of Andrew's attention to important details.

Naively, I saw this course was 39 hours long and figured that I could run through it in a week however obviously there are coding exercises and I took electronic notes as I went, as I used to do in college courses. This is a lot of content and it is worth spending the extra time to go through it properly. All told, the course took me a month to complete. The great news is that I could already take what I had learned a quarter of the way through to start to build new user interfaces. 
The presentation is very slick; Andrew has a clear lecturing style and the screen capture flow and pristine audio flow seamlessly.

The course covers a lot of ground from introducing React and Redux/Hooks to setting up a production build environment to getting started with SCSS and Firebase. Having finished the course, I have an idea for a mini-project that will use most of the material and which would have been more work to complete using my old tech stack.

This is a college-quality course with the difference that the lecturer and students are always on time.

results.content:
This is a FANTASTIC React course for beginners, taught by an EXCELLENT teacher.

I have watched several "React intro courses", which always left me quite baffled, confused and, ultimately, not productive. I am building a MERN web app with a couple of friends, and this course is really helping me out understand all there is to know to React to become a productive team member. 

The course is a little slow paced (and it may be slightly too slow paced if you already have tons of experience with JS frameworks), but this also means that there are no gaps in knowledge and nothing is rushed or skipped. The instructor knows his stuff, he explains every steps thoroughly and really takes an effort to give challenges to reinforce the knowledge just acquired. 100% satisfied!

results.content: I have heard others say that Andrew is the best instructor on Udemy, and from what I have seen I have to agree. I 100% recommend this guy. If you want to be the person who understands these topics deeply, learn from him. He gives you a deep understanding of how and why things work the way they do while still keeping things concise, and he gives you a challenge in pretty much every lecture. Things just stick.  I took Andrew's Node.js course first, and then did this one, and got a job using React shortly after. It was my first coding job so there was a lot to learn, but I already had a solid grasp of React and even understood some things that the senior devs who worked there already did not. 100% recommend this guy. I've taken a few courses from other instructors and they were all pretty good, but nothing close to Andrew's work.

results.content:
The first (core) part of the course is great for beginners. The instructor gradually progresses material, requiring you first  to implement solution in "old fashioned" javascript style and then shows how this could be done more efficiently with ES6. I really love this approach, as it pinpoints advantages and disadvantages of compared solutions.

Non-core parts starting from Redux are not so great. Concepts of topics are not as well explained (e.g., event driven design) and code does not fully follow industry standards (naming conventions, what should be tested/what not, directory structure, ...). Don't get me wrong, it's still good for beginners but not as useful for more experienced. For such a long course I'd expect progression of experience level during the course.

For experienced engineer, I'd recommend watching with 1.5-2x speed.

results.content:
Review from me--a Senior Developer,

First off, why would a Senior Dev take this course? Well, part of my job is bringing junior-mid level devs up to speed during their onboarding process.  So I take new courses to not only teach myself better techniques, but mainly so that I recommend outside training.  When in comes to Udemy, I've taken about _all_ of the courses between Andrew Mead and Stephen Grider.  This one is by far the best.  I'm glad he took the time to go as deep as he did.  

Teaching style is a matter of personal preference, but in terms of building real world, scalable projects, Andrew takes the prize.  Unless you've built a large application, you may not notice the subtleties: Having a reducer's default state live in an object outside of the function body, defining your filter service outside of the reducer, going through webpack config and on and on. The testing section alone deserves it's own review.  This is an incredibly thorough course and while both instructors have a nice attention to detail, this one is what I'll be recommending to bring our developers up to speed.

results.content:
This is easily the best React course I've found on Udemy or anywhere else. It's often difficult for me to find material that covers the middle ground of technical content - many courses assume you're starting from square one and others assume you've got a comp sci degree. This course is perfect for people who are familiar with basic web development and want to get into the tools real professionals are using.

The thing I like most about Andrew's teaching style is the depth he's able to go into without making the student feel dumb. React courses suffer from this a lot - to be relevant, you need to cover other things like Redux and Webpack, but it's easy to get lost in the weeds. Andrew does an amazing job of explaining how these technologies work, including configuration and the different available options (he even explains ones that aren't used in the course, but are common in real world scenarios).

When Andrew titled this the "Complete" React Course, he was not exaggerating. I've taken a few of his other courses, and will keep taking them because I believe he's one of the best web dev instructors out there. 

I can't think of a single negative thing to say. If you're interested in learning React, this is the course to take.

The thing I like most about Andrew's teaching style is the depth he's able to go into without making the student feel dumb. React courses suffer from this a lot - to be relevant, you need to cover other things like Redux and Webpack, but it's easy to get lost in the weeds. Andrew does an amazing job of explaining how these technologies work, including configuration and the different available options (he even explains ones that aren't used in the course, but are common in real world scenarios).

When Andrew titled this the "Complete" React Course, he was not exaggerating. I've taken a few of his other courses, and will keep taking them because I believe he's one of the best web dev instructors out there.

I can't think of a single negative thing to say. If you're interested in learning React, this is the course to take.

I really enjoyed taking this course.  It was very comprehensive and gave me the confidence to try and start creating real world apps on my own.

Andrew is a very good instructor.  He explains things in detail and shows that he is really an expert in the subject matter.  At certain points I would have liked him to slow down the pace a little bit, especially the sections after redux.  I have to rewind the video several times so I can catch up.  This is not an issue with his teaching though.  It was more of my inexperience with the new ES6 syntax.

All in all I think he did a very good job with this course.  I look forward to take taking more courses from him in the future.

results.content:
So far, and this is very early stages, I've been happy with how the content has been explained.  In the past I've taken classes where a lot of the content was either dismissed by saying "you don't need to know x,y,z" or "if you want to know more about x,y, and z, you can google it."  While I appreciated those teachers for not wanting to overwhelming us newcomers, I was discouraged by how quickly they would gloss over the concepts.  Annnnnyway, Andrew has been good about being clear and descriptive while not going over too much, too fast.  

I also have never created a react app from scratch, (only using react-create-app) so it was cool to see how to do that.  Again.  I have a long way to go in the course, but it's been enjoyable.


UPDATED:  I finished the course.  It was great to walk away with two completed apps.  I don't know if the Jest portion of the course could have been integrated differently.  It was very useful to learn, but it got me a little derailed from learning redux.  Overall, a super helpful course.  Worth doing if you are interested in getting into React in a serious way.

Great React/Redux course - very helpful and indepth explanations! I love that Andrew doesn't use CreateReactApp in this course and instead shows you the nitty-gritty of how to configure it all yourself! Very helpful rather than using the magical-black-box of CRA.

Took off 0.5 stars just because there are some portions that, if I hadn't done a handful of beginner React/Redux tutorials before, would have been confusing. The explanation of Redux could use some work for example... even with that said, it's still a really great course that I highly recommend.

results.content:
Andrew is an infectious and inspiring teacher and the constant challenges make this an interesting and interactive experience.

Many other courses & teachers start you off installing things like babel & webpack without ever taking you through the basics of what these are actually doing. Andrew shows you how to work without these utilities and then adds them after you understand what they will be doing. This philosophy extends throughout the course, so I really feel like I am coming to grips with the subject, instead of just typing in code.

I definitely recommend and will watch out for other courses from this instructor.

results.content: Andrew gives detailed explanations in simple language that anyone can understand. I'm taking both his node.js course, and his react course and have been impressed with how quickly I'm picking up the basics. The challenges he includes in most of the videos provide the practical knowledge you need to really understand what your learning. You're not just coding along, as happens with many programming courses, you're figuring out how to make the code work for you. I'm excited to build my portfolio with the projects in the course, and then to branch out to work on a few ideas of my own! Definitely would recommend this course for anyone that wants to expand their coding abilities.

results.content:
I entered this with a software developer's background, but mostly back-end work - i.e. weak JavaScript, no exposure to React. This course did a great job of teaching me how to use the React library and explained just enough JavaScript & ES6 so that it wasn't a barrier. I feel like I learned a ton, and Andrew was very engaging. The new section at the end on hooks was awesome!

If I were to suggest anything, it would be to spend more time on best practices, i.e. why you should do things a certain way or which way professional React devs tend to build their apps. Some time is spent on this - especially in the testing sections - but more would be great, especially for folks who are new to React and/or trying to become professional front-end developers.

results.content:
Overall 'fantastic' and definitely 5 stars.

As a seasoned web developer, the course is a really good fit for learning React. I like that the basics were very comprehensively taught, as it explained clearly what the different core modules are and the role they play. By the time the course reached the 'Redux' section the learning curve is steeper which is good for progression. Andrews format of introducing new concepts, demonstrating and then finally setting a challenge is great as it lets you go away and practice/experiment with the new skill(s) and gain confidence.

Additionally, the 3rd party services Firebase used for data storage and authentication, in my opinion, is a good choice at this level, as it is simple to integrate and is well documented.

results.content:
Had a great time learning about React & Redux in this course. I was a total newbie to code, but was curious and feel like I actually learned many useful skills in this course. The testing section felt like it dragged on at times, but I was telling my developer friends about it and they commended me for doing due diligence by creating test cases (apparently it is often overlooked).

Though I don't feel like I could go out and create a product that is ready for market, I do feel like this course set a great foundation to continue learning about React app development and thinking critically about my future projects. Many thanks to Andrew & Team for putting this course together! :)

results.content:
This is the best programming course I've ever taken so far (and I've taken a few). I'm fairly confident with regular front end (without a framework) and with Node back end, but I've never touched React before. This course was just perfect.

Pros:
- Everything is extremely well explained.
- Instructor is fun, energetic, encouraging and never boring to listen to.
- Course gets into many things you need in real-world development, such as testing, Babel, Webpack, new ES6 features, etc.
- Covers React and other necessary things to a great extent.

Cons:
- Course doesn't go 100% deep on any topic. E.g. not all of Webpack, Babel, testing or ES6 is covered. (Mind you I don't really think this is a con as you would need many courses for all of those.)
- Not all of React was covered. For example I've encountered one technique before using "ref: /* something */" which wasn't mentioned during the course.

Overall:
I honestly found this to be the best programming course I've ever taken.

Things like Webpack, Babel and testing were on my list to learn for so long. I even tried to learn testing for a while but gave up and decided to leave it for the future. There's just a ton of stuff concerning testing and without an instructor it's much harder to even find out what technologies are used for testing, what you should learn, and then you have to actually learn it in an efficient way.

Getting the initial knowledge from this course was just what I needed. The instructor covers things like Webpack, Babel, testing, ES6 and such to a good standard, which then makes further learning on your own easy and possible. During the course I took detours to study all of those further on my own, and I would say I've gained a great grasp on them.

Even though I mention that not all of React was covered, I have the same opinion that this course is amazing and sets you up for learning everything else you need on your own easily.

As a final thought, I'd say that if you have any deficiencies in Webpack, Babel, ES6, testing, and of course React, DEFINITELY get this course.
Maybe if you're interested purely on React and nothing else, then find a course that's purely on React and nothing else. Otherwise this course is amazing. 10 / 10 would recommend, and I have no affiliation with the instructor or this course whatsoever.

As a final thought, I'd say that if you have any deficiencies in Webpack, Babel, ES6, testing, and of course React, DEFINITELY get this course.
Maybe if you're interested purely on React and nothing else, then find a course that's purely on React and nothing else. Otherwise this course is amazing. 10 / 10 would recommend, and I have no affiliation with the instructor or this course whatsoever.

results.content:
The course does a great job at covering most of the important aspects of React, however, with the Redux section and onwards, I felt that the pace became too fast for the complexity of the tasks at hand, so I believe that the 2nd half of the course could be more beginner-friendly.

I also believe that many of the videos could have been broken down into shorter videos. As it stands now, most of the videos average around 15 minutes because they cover more than 1 topic. I think that splitting the videos in shorter ones, each one focusing on only 1 topic, is better in the long run, because it's easier to watch them and you can also revisit them if you forgot something. With the current structure, I sometimes got lost and it was really hard to go back to the point where they first explained the part I was having trouble with, because it wasn't the main topic of any video.

Asides from that, I feel that Andrew is very experienced in the matter and his delivery is engaging. Adam the assistant is also super helpful and fast to respond to issues.

results.content:
Overall, Andrew does a great job explaining concepts and going through examples.  However, sometimes this is to the detriment of time.  Basic concepts like including Git commits and pushes can be glossed over or skipped entirely (though to be fair, he started to do this towards the end of the course).  A lot of times he doesn't utilize quick shortcuts, like using Option + up/down arrow to move lines of code, or Command + D to highlight multiple instances of text.  He could easily teach these early on and then utilize throughout the course to speed things up.

This is really my only nitpick about Andrew's courses and it's just that...a nitpick.  The content is usually geared towards those with (near) zero experience in the subject, so completeness is good, but it's overdone sometimes.  I usually end up watching the videos at 1.5x speed and skip forward a lot because of this.

results.content:
I just completed the course and had a very pleasant learning experience.

Andrew assumes no prior knowledge about the whole react, npm ecosystem and there is a very high success rate of completing the entire course, gaining new skills that gives us the confidence to develop real world applications on our own.

The feature of the course that I felt is the most useful is the process of guiding us to set up environment: webpack, testing, and eventually boilerplate.

In particular, these are the topics that I felt were covered extremely well:
Webpack - Notorious for its poor documentation
Testing - Few instructors would even cover the subject of testing because it is confusing and tedious, and that is why I gave up on testing previously.
Firebase authentication - Great real world application
Boilerplate - One of the best part. No one would like to set up babel, webpack, jest, enzyme every single time. I hate it too :O

Thank you Andrew, I am eagerly waiting for your next course :)

results.content:
Hi Andrew and Adam,

Thanks you so much for this course, Andrew you are amazing teacher, this is the second course I've took made by you (first was javascript bootcamp). I have to say I've learnt a lot, it was good how you explain how things work behind the scenes instead of using "create-react-app" and start coding. I feel that I'm ready to create whatever idea I have, or just simple websites. And thanks to Adam for the great work is doing replying all the questions, I know it's not a easy task. I am not giving you full five stars because I felt like the course need an update in some lectures, also I know it's hard to maintain a course after 3 years and I miss some good explanation about in which situations we need to use hooks or class components, context API or Redux. But it was a great experience anyways. I recommend the course to everybody.
results.content_html:
Hi Andrew and Adam,

Thanks you so much for this course, Andrew you are amazing teacher, this is the second course I've took made by you (first was javascript bootcamp). I have to say I've learnt a lot, it was good how you explain how things work behind the scenes instead of using "create-react-app" and start coding. I feel that I'm ready to create whatever idea I have, or just simple websites. And thanks to Adam for the great work is doing replying all the questions, I know it's not a easy task. I am not giving you full five stars because I felt like the course need an update in some lectures, also I know it's hard to maintain a course after 3 years and I miss some good explanation about in which situations we need to use hooks or class components, context API or Redux. But it was a great experience anyways. I recommend the course to everybody.

results.content:
This is one of the best courses on Udemy. Complex topics are explained very clearly and precisely, but the trouth is they need a lot of patience and work if you are not an experienced  programmer. 
Years ago I had some  experience in traditional server side programming   (php, and the like). I have also some  familiarity of Node.js  and Express, but React. has been very hard for me to grasp. Now I understand quite a lot of it and also of React Router and try to get my hand dirty with a small hobby project.  I still struggle with Redux but start to understand it to some extend.
 Thank you Andrew for this course. Without it, learning React would be so much harder if not impossible for me

results.content:
Andrew Mead is one of the best teachers on this site. That's a bold statement, but allow me to elaborate.

He has a fantastic understanding of the material and not only does he show `how` something works, but explains `why` it exists and `what` problem it solves. That delivery was especially helpful as he transitioned our code from ES5 to ES6.

He frequently quizzes you in the videos, to confirm and consolidate your understanding, before going over the quizzed content together. Personally, I find this type of delivery works extremely well.

All udemy project managers and editors should be forced to watch all of the videos in this course, in order to learn how course material should be organized and explained. results.content:
I have already taken two other courses by Andrew. I was never disappointed with either and this one also delivers to the expectations. I have only done 20% of the course and I am immensely enjoying the material.
If you are a total beginner, I recommend doing Andrew's courses in the following order:
1. The modern javascript bootcamp.
2. This one.
3. The complete node.js developer course.

The good thing Andrew does is that the coding techniques he explains in his javascript course carry over to the other two courses so when you experience them in React or Node you find them very familiar. Really well done.

In this course it just feels like we do it the bad way for no reason, just to change it to a "better" way kinda. Didn't work out for me in this course, sorry andrew.

results.content:
The instructor is so easy to understand and he some how manages to explain everything in great detail without treating you like a child or being long winded. I feel actively engaged the entire time and do not feel myself drifting off or having to go back to catch things I'd missed as I sometimes do with other instructors. 

Another great thing about this course is all of the working examples that are explained and the frequent challenges where you are asked to practice what you are learning. There is lots of hands on learning, but it doesn't seem to be the standard copy/paste tutorial. Instead, the work along stuff is engaging and everything is explained well. I personally find that quizzes are not all that helpful and so far I have not seen any of them in this course.

results.content:
In my opinion, this is one of the most comprehensive React courses out there. Andrew teaches everything you need to know about creating a real-world React application from scratch. More importantly, most of the content is up to date. I'm very thankful that Andrew has shown me what most of the modern React developers out there are doing.
I wish to share my personal story here in case you may find yourself identifying with me. Prior to this course, I had known a little bit about React. I even tried to build a quite complex app on React only (without Redux and stuff), and, of course, it turned out to be a spaghetti mess.  Afterwards, I realized that I had to learn Redux to do it properly. However, the all-on-my-own researching & learning process was quite daunting despite all the docs, the guides and the video tutorials from professionals. Therefore, I decided to buy this course, and thank God, it's probably one of the wisest decisions in my life.  Thanks to Andrew's crystal-clear instructions, I was able to get a good grasp of Redux and many other important things in a very short period of time (I actually finished this course in about 2 weeks, spending at least 3 hours a day on it). Ultimately, I now have everything I need to start a personal project on my own with the additional help of  and Firebase and Jest (a crucial testing tool - and I only got to know the importance of unit testing during this course). 
FYI, I'm a foreign student coming from Vietnam. I'm not too good at listening English, at least not to the level of a native speaker. But I never found it hard to understand Andrew. In fact, I sometimes speeded up the video to 1.5x and still had no trouble listening. Andrew definitely has a very clear accent and a very intriguing way of explaining stuff. I wish there could be such quality React courses as this one in my school or my country.
I highly recommend this course to everyone who is thinking of learning React & Redux from scratch. Don't waste too much time out there researching things anymore.

results.content: This is the third time I've tried to learn the React ecosystem, and I wish I'd found this course first. Great pacing. Good balance of instruction and exercises/challenges. He does have a couple sections where we red/green test, but overall we're writing tests for code that exists.

results.content:
Thanks for another great course Andrew. This course took a while to get through but I sure feel like I learned a lot.

I really appreciated all the prompts to try things myself before seeing how you did it. While your explanations and examples are really clear, it is much different when called up to do it without following along.

I might suggest adding some information on recommended resources that would help keep abreast of new React related developments, particularly npm packages.  

Kevin

results.content:
This was my first course from Udemy and I was thoroughly impressed. I was surprised at the responsiveness of the instructor, the bar has been set pretty high. The day a major release of react was made, he had posted an upgrade guide and updated videos shortly there after.

He does a great job of explaining the "why" instead of just having you type code. In addition to demonstrating a great understanding of react and redux, his explanations of the features that ES6 adds and development  tools, make this course worthwhile for an experienced developer that is new to JavaScript.

Andrew has almost made me like JavaScript...

results.content:
This course is above and beyond anything I expected.

It took me from wanting to learn react with redux to now wanting to figure out how to develop react with redux full stack applications with testing. I knew eventually I would get there but I didn't realize this one course would push me there so fast. I didn't even take this course for all of the content that was covered. 

React, redux, webpack, sass, git, jest, firebase etc, and on top of that, the Q/A section is by far one of the best. Andrew and Adam are there to answer your questions at any point in time with fast responding. You don't get that with many courses on udemy. A lot of courses aren't kept up with and instructors sometimes never respond. This is a huge plus for this course. 

If you're looking for a React with Redux course to take, just take this one. You won't be disappointed with the results. 

My only advice, don't rush it. After learning a section, put the course on hold and go build something with what you learned. There's so much to dissect that if you just plow through the course looking to finish it you will end up losing most of it. Take it slow and make sure you understand the concepts so when you finally finish, you feel like you will be able to replicate everything that was covered.

results.content:
I've tried taking other React+Redux courses, and while they were by no means bad, This one is just too good! 

Rather than skim through the things that make React React, Andrew patiently explains every nut and bolt that composes the application and progressively improves it with more efficient code. It helps you understand the original intent behind the optimized implementation, and make a lot more sense out of the whole thing. 

I'm only 30% through, but I'm eager to make more progress on this course!

UPDATE: After completing the course, my original assessment holds up. Although I struggled trudging through the testing section, I do understand the importance of it and I can't think of any one way to improve it. Great work on this course!
